DOC.HEAD: Hearings Open Into Police Eavesdropping Practices
DOC.TEXT: Police departments across the country routinely tape conversations between jailed suspects and their lawyers, a congressional hearing was told Monday. The hearing by the courts subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee grew out of a Connecticut auto case that came to light earlier this year. But state or local police or corrections officers in at least 12 other states routinely record lawyer-client conversations, said the subcommittee chairman, Rep. Robert W. Kastenmeier, D-Wis. ``A clear pattern is emerging across the country,'' said Kastenmeier. ``It is unfortunate but likely that as we explore what happened in these states, information about other states will come to light.'' Kastenmeier said information gathered by the subcommttee indicates that some form of bugging or wiretapping of conversations between jailed suspects and their attorneys has gone on in Rhode Island, West Virginia, Georgia, New Mexico, Oregon, Alaska, Wyoming, Vermont, Indiana, Utah, Nebraska and New Jersey. Antonio Califa, legislative counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union, detailed several instances of police taping: _In Rhode Island, state police since 1988 have taped incoming and outgoing calls on a system that connects the state's five barracks. According to Califa, the U.S. attorney has begun a preliminary investigation. _In West Virginia, state police have been taping telephone conversations from suspects to their families and lawyers for 20 years, Califa said. Callers are not warned that the calls are being recorded. _The Utah Civil Liberties Union is planning a lawsuit alleging that the state Department of Corrections routinely taped conversations between convicted prison inmates and their attorneys. Federal law forbids telephone taping except when investigatrs obtain a court order based on probable cause in a criminal investigation or when both parties to the conversation agree to the taping. Many state laws mirror the 1968 federal statute but some permit taping if only one party to the conversation consents. Monday's hearing included a videotape of a telephone conversation on August 5, 1988, between a suspect in a Connecticut vehicular homicide case and his attorney. During trial a Connecticut State Police officer testified that the call was recorded as part of routine department policy. An investigation by The Hartford Courant revealed that the secret tape-recording by state police was widespread, prompting Gov. William A. O'Neill to order an immediate halt to the taping of attorney-client calls. The revelations cost Public Safety Commissioner and State Police Commander Lester J. Forst his job. A later state investigation concluded that the tapes were not used to illegally gather evidence against suspects. The Connecticut State Police have insisted from the start that the tapes were not listened to. Attorneys Elliot B. Spector and Marcia J. Gleeson, representing Connecticut and 19 defendants including two top former state police officials, wrote to Kastenmeier on Saturday that the witness list for Monday's hearing would only expose one side of the story. ``The news media, some public figures and criminal defense attorneys hysterically characterized these events as criminal acts amounting to a national crisis,'' Gleeson and Spector wrote. ``I would hope that the committee will take a more cautious approach to this issue.'' Gleeson said committee staff members rejected offers to provide an opposing point of view in the hearing. Members of Kastenmeier's staff said the committee sought to question Connecticut State Police Lt. Col. John Mulligan about the taping practices but that Mulligan refused.
